awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Urban Informatics for Smart, Sustainable Cities: Toward a Data-Driven Understanding of Metropolitan Energy Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET 1653772; PI: Kontokosta, Constantine E. 

This project will use data-driven methodologies to advance fundamental understanding of urban energy dynamics through a coupled model of urban energy demand, behavior, and infrastructure. The work seeks to maximize impact by supporting evidenced-based urban energy policy, public and private decision-making, and infrastructure investment to more effectively design, implement, and evaluate energy reduction strategies. Using a diverse, comprehensive, and unique collection of data acquired by the PI, the research aims to tackle the following: (1) What drives energy use within and across cities? (2) What are the socio-technical dynamics of building energy consumption? (3) How and why do energy conservation measures and retrofit opportunities vary by building type, city, and region? (4) What are the spatial-temporal patterns of energy use in cities? (5) How do urban and regional policies impact energy efficiency and cost savings over time?

The work in urban informatics and metropolitan energy dynamics is focused on developing new analytical approaches, coupled with an array of building, land use, and energy data from U.S. and international cities, to advance the fundamental understanding of the patterns and determinants of urban energy demand and GHG emissions from the built environment and their impacts on human well-being. This will be achieved by integrating methods from civil and systems engineering, data science, and computational social science to develop data-driven models to support decision-making through the extraction of actionable intelligence from big data. This research will  (1) integrate an array of building, neighborhood, and city level data across tens of thousands of buildings and multiple cities, (2) utilize new sources of urban energy data to create a large, non-self-selected dataset, and (3) simultaneously examine physical, environmental, social, and behavioral components of urban dynamics to create a multi-scalar model of energy demand and reduction potentials across metropolitan areas. The research seeks to provide the analytical rigor to support objective, evidenced-based policies that will create a framework for performance-driven evaluation of proposed and implemented strategies. The education plan will facilitate development of a network of students trained in building energy efficiency, urban informatics, and urban sustainability, as well as foster greater public awareness of the scale and importance of addressing energy challenges in cities. The research and education activities will build on an existing relationship with city agencies, industry collaborators, and the MetroLab Network - a group of 34 city-university partnerships focused on data solutions to urban challenges - to provide the foundation for smart, sustainable cities in the U.S. and globally.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project was to address the significant societal challenge of energy use and carbon emissions in cities using data and computation.  By integrating methods and concepts from data science, engineering, and the social sciences, the project developed new ways to analyze and model the interactions between physical, environmental, behavioral, and socioeconomic systems in the urban context. The project achieved significant advances in the fundamental understanding of urban energy dynamics, as well as the application of data-driven and machine learning approaches to energy and climate policy and planning in practice. An important emphasis of this project was identifying, measuring, and analyzing the socioeconomic disparities associated with energy use and carbon emissions in cities, and prioritizing social equity and environmental justice in urban sustainability through data-driven decision-making. Specific accomplishments include:

Predictive modeling of energy use in buildings: The project developed new models and analysis of the drivers of energy use in buildings, and created new tools to measure energy performance across a range of building types.

Racial and economic disparities in energy efficiency and energy cost burdens: Energy inefficiency disproportionately impacts lower-income and minority households. In several studies, we determined that subsidized and low-income housing is less efficient than comparable market-rate properties, and that the cost burden of energy inefficient housing falls on communities least able to afford it. We explored ways to leverage new data streams and methods to account for energy costs in broader housing affordability indicators. This work received a Best Paper award from the Journal of the American Planning Association.

Evaluation of urban climate policy on energy use and carbon emissions: The adoption of local building energy policies ? from mandatory energy benchmarking to energy audit requirements and carbon emissions intensity targets ? has accelerated in the past several years, with a significant number of U.S. cities including such policies as part of their sustainability strategies. Using New York City as experimental test case, we evaluated the effect of several of these policies on energy use and carbon emissions from buildings.

Energy retrofit investment decision-making and financial returns: A significant mechanism to reduce energy consumption and carbon emissions in cities is the retrofitting of existing buildings. This project developed new machine learning decision support tools to advance virtual or automated energy audits, and analyzed the financial returns to energy retrofits in a large sample of buildings. The findings support both the benefit of data-driven decision tools and the potentially significant returns to retrofit investments.

High resolution modeling of urban carbon emissions and prediction of future energy demand: Ultimately, the goal of this project was to collect, integrate, and analyze data to develop new high-resolution models of urban energy use and carbon emissions. We created a hourly, 250-meter grid model of carbon emissions for New York City, combining machine learning and energy model-based approaches to estimate carbon emissions from buildings, along with traffic and mobility-derived predictions of vehicular emissions. A preliminary version of this work received an award from the UN Global Pulse Data for Climate Action Challenge. In addition, we developed new methods to predict neighborhood change and future energy demand in order to estimate emerging spatial-temporal patterns of carbon emissions at the community scale.

The impact of this project spanned a wide range of disciplines, including engineering, data science, economics, public policy, and urban planning, and reached a diversity of government agencies and non-profit organizations. The data tools, methodologies, and models developed during this project have been used by multiple cities to clean, integrate, and analyze local energy use and carbon emissions data. A data visualization tool, available through the New York City Mayor?s Office, allows users to explore, analyze, and extract energy, water, and carbon emissions data for large buildings in New York City. The tool is available here: https://on.nyc.gov/benchmarkingmap.

The project engaged collaborators and partners across a range of city, state, and federal agencies, non-profit organizations, and the private sector. Students and researchers, including master?s and PhD students, postdoctoral researchers, and research scientists, contributed to the project and engaged in professional development opportunities through participation in project meetings and related seminars, presentations at conferences and events, and training through teaching and educational programming. Through this project, a new course at NYU on urban informatics for sustainable cities was created, as well as a new PhD program in urban systems through the Tandon School of Engineering. In addition, the work contributed to multiple student projects through the Capstone program of the M.S. in Applied Urban Science and Informatics offered by NYU?s Center for Urban Science and Progress. Material related to this project was incorporated into several classes taught by project personnel, including the PI?s course on civic analytics and urban intelligence. Additional information on products and outputs related to this project are available at the PI?s lab website: http://www.urbanintelligencelab.org.
